Dear Mr. Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
2

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation While placed at the facility Youth A experienced physical abuse
from staff and other youth.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed over the phone on 04/10/2023
and had no additional information to report. She stated Youth A’s
parent likely had more information and provided contact
information for her.
Youth A’s parent was interviewed over the phone on 04/10/2023.
During this interview Youth A’s parent reported several concerns
and allegations against the facility regarding her daughter’s time
placed there. She specifically recalled concerns regarding an
incident that she believed occurred in October involving her
daughter and a staff member that allowed her daughter to get beat
up by other youth. She believed the staff at fault in that incident
was Supervisor 1. Youth A’s parent stated her daughter brought
up this incident to her for the first time the day prior. Youth A’s
parent stated she had called local law enforcement and Youth A
was interviewed regarding this incident at her new placement.
Youth A was interviewed on 04/12/2023 during an announced,
face to face visit at her new placement. This interview occurred in
the presence of a staff member from the placement and Youth A’s
parent at Youth A’s request. When asked about the incident in
question, Youth A stated Supervisor 1 had put her hands on Youth
A’s chest in an attempt to move her during an altercation, and it
felt like she was shoved. Youth A recalled Supervisor 1 denied
pushing her in that movement, but that was not how Youth A
interpreted that part of the interaction. Youth A recalled being
pushed by either a staff or youth, she could not clarify who, and
falling to the floor. She clarified at no point did any staff attempt to
restrain her while she was fighting with other youth, but only that
Supervisor 1 pushed her. She recalled Youth D choking her from
behind as well but could not be specific as to how this part of the
incident ended. Youth A also remembered Youth C and Youth E
pulled hair out of her head during the fighting. Youth A stated she
felt like the entire incident lasted for about 30 minutes. Youth A
stated she had not felt like talking more about the incident to her
parent or anyone else because she was scared that it could have
been used against her. When asked to elaborate as to why she
may have had that fear, Youth A could not provide any specific
reasons. After the altercation Youth A stated she felt lumps on the
back of her head and that her back was hurting. Youth A clarified
she felt like she was never held down during the incident.
3

Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 04/21/2023 with DHHS Worker
1 and Law Enforcement during an announced, face to face visit to
the facility. She stated she remembered the incident in question
and confirmed that she was involved in it. Supervisor 1 stated the
entire fight began when there was discord between Youth A and
Youth D, with Youth A eventually attempting to fight Youth D.
Supervisor 1 stated she was standing in between Youth A and
Youth D when this occurred and denied putting her hands on
either youth at that time. Supervisor 1 stated Youth A was able to
get around her and to Youth D to start fighting. She stated she
was able to talk Youth A into stopping the fight and moving to her
own personal aisle by her bed, which Youth A did without any
incident and without Supervisor 1 having to put her hands on her.
Supervisor 1 recalled Youth E then began to escalate and argue
with Youth A. Supervisor 1 stated other staff became involved at
that point but could not immediately recall who they were. Youth
E then swung over the back of Supervisor 1 and attempted to hit
Youth A, from what Supervisor 1 recalled. She believed Youth A
was hit on the top of her head by Youth E. Supervisor 1 stated
she separated the two youth by physically moving Youth A. When
asked to be more specific on how this occurred, Supervisor 1
described her actions as placing her hands on the outside of
Youth A’s shoulders while facing her. Supervisor 1 stated she
then moved Youth A away from the other youth and Youth A
complied and walked with her. At no point during this part of their
interaction did Youth A attempt to get away from Supervisor 1, nor
did she fall to the ground according to Supervisor 1. At this point
Supervisor 1 recalled Youth C and Youth E again attempting to hit
Youth A. She described seeing Youth C run from around the right
side of Supervisor 1 to grab Youth A’s hair, causing Youth A to fall
to the floor. At the same time Supervisor 1 remembered seeing
Youth C go around her left side and attempt to hit Youth A while
Youth A fell to the ground. Supervisor 1’s interview had to end at
that time and was resumed on 04/26/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
and Law Enforcement during an announced, face to face visit to
the facility. During this interview, Supervisor 1 clarified how she
had put her hands on Youth A the one time she recalled this
occurring during the incident in question. She demonstrated
putting each hand on the top and side of Youth A’s shoulders and
walking Youth A backwards. Supervisor 1 reiterated that there
was no pushing involved in this interaction and Youth A moved
with her cooperatively. Supervisor 1 stated she believed this
physical contact was necessary because of the fast escalation of
fighting between Youth A and the other youth involved.
4

Staff 1 was interviewed on 04/21/2023 with DHHS Worker 1 and
Law Enforcement during an announced, face to face visit to the
facility. Staff 1 initially struggled to recall the incident in question
involving Youth A but stated she did remember after recalling
Youth D throwing juice at Youth A. She stated that began a fight
involving several other youths. Staff 1 recalled that Youth A and
Youth D were throwing punches at each other quickly, and that
Youth C and Youth E were also involved in attempting to punch
Youth A during the incident. Staff 1 stated she believed the
aggressor in all this was Youth A. She did not recall seeing Youth
A be pushed by any other youth or staff during the incident. Staff
1 could not remember what other staff were involved in the
incident other than Supervisor 1. She recalled seeing Supervisor
1 attempt to de-escalate the situation by standing in between
Youth A and Youth D. Staff 1 clarified she did not see Supervisor
1 put her hands on Youth A or Youth D during that part of the
incident, or the rest of the incident until it deescalated.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 05/09/2023 with DHHS Worker 1 and
Law Enforcement during an announced, face to face visit to the
facility. She stated she recalled the incident in question. Staff 2
stated Youth A and Youth D began fighting with each other. In her
opinion Youth A was the aggressor but Youth C, Youth D and
Youth E all started to fight back against her. Staff 2 recalled
seeing Supervisor 1 attempt to stand in between Youth A and
Youth D and telling Youth A something to the effect of “It’s not
worth it” as she attempted to de-escalate the youth. Staff 2 stated
she and Supervisor 1 both attempted to separate Youth C and
Youth A after Youth C attempted to punch Youth A. Staff 2
described this separation attempt as only verbal and not having
any physical contact with either youth. Staff 2 recalled seeing
Youth A standing all the way up to that part of the incident, and
not on the ground from falling. Staff 2 stated she could not recall
exactly how the fight ended, but she remembered seeing Youth A
sitting on the ground after everyone was deescalated debriefing
the incident with another staff member, who she could not recall.
Staff 2 stated she did not see anyone get bit during the incident.
She also could not recall seeing anyone being kicked, or having
their hair pulled. Staff 2 stated she believed Youth A was never
pushed to the ground during the incident itself but sat down
afterwards on her own. Staff 2 believed the entire incident lasted
roughly eight minutes. She stated she did not see any staff push
or hit Youth A or any other youth during the incident.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 05/09/2023 with DHHS
Worker 1. She stated she could remember the incident because
5

of how it began, with Youth A and Youth D and juice boxes being
thrown. Staff 3 recalled seeing Supervisor 1 attempt to de-
escalate the situation as it evolved, specifically speaking with
Youth A. Staff 3 stated the situation escalated very quickly after
that, with Youth C attempting to hit Youth A and Youth A trying to
fight back. Staff 3 stated she recalled seeing Staff 1 attempt to
block Youth A from getting to Youth D, but doing so without having
physical contact with Youth A. Staff 3 stated she never heard any
of the other staff instruct any of the youth to fight, nor did she
believe any of the staff involved failed to act quickly enough to
attempt to de-escalate the situation. Staff 3 also stated no other
staff members pushed any youth despite the chaotic situation, and
neither did she. Staff 3 stated she never saw Youth A fall to the
floor during the incident. She stated it was possible that Youth D
may have been able to have Youth A by the hair during the
incident and she could not be sure if that did or did not occur.
Youth B was interviewed over the phone with Law Enforcement
and DHHS Worker 2 on 05/10/2023. She confirmed she had
previously been placed at the facility with Youth A and she
remembered that Youth A had gotten into a lot of physical
altercations, so she had initial trouble recalling which one she was
being asked about. Youth B stated she did remember the incident
in question and called this one “the worst” of them all. Youth B
stated at one point in the fight, Youth A had three girls on her
attempting to hit her. She identified these youth as Youth C,
Youth E and could not identify the third youth. Youth B stated the
whole incident began because Youth A and Youth D had gotten in
to a verbal altercation. Youth A took a juice box and, while a staff
was attempting to verbally de-escalate and stand between the two
youth, Youth A squirted the juice box in the face of Youth D.
Youth B couldn't remember which staff that was specifically, but
she did remember Supervisor 1 being involved in much of the
altercation. Youth B stated she could only recall Supervisor 1
attempting to verbally redirect any of the youth involved. Youth B
didn’t believe any staff were physical or put their hands on Youth
A during the altercation. She recalled seeing Youth C, Youth D,
and Youth E hitting Youth A at various points during the incident
but never as a result of staff not attempting to intervene or doing
so not quickly enough.
Youth C was interviewed over the phone with Law Enforcement
and DHHS Worker 3 on 05/10/2023. Youth C stated she was in
the unit and recalled the incident in question. She recalled the
entire incident began because Youth A had stated to Youth E that
she had a crush on another youth in the program, and Youth D
6

and Youth E told staff about this information. This upset Youth A,
from what Youth C could recall. As the situation escalated, Youth
C recalled Supervisor 1, Staff 1 and Staff 2 present. Youth C
believed all the staff that interacted initially with Youth A had
stayed hands off with her, but she was trying to jump around them
to get to Youth D with which she was upset. Youth C believed
Youth A fell to the ground while attempting to get around
Supervisor 1, and then got back up and attempted to hit
Supervisor 1 and Staff 1. At that point Youth C believed Youth D
was able to get behind Youth A and choke her around her neck.
Youth C stated she could not remember many specifics after that
other than seeing a couple of other youth that she could not
identify attempting to hit Youth A. She did not recall if anyone
pulled Youth A’s hair. Youth C stated she did not see any staff
involved hit Youth A during the altercation and stated that they
mostly remained hands off.
Youth D was interviewed over the phone with Law Enforcement
and DHHS Worker 4 on 05/11/2023. She stated she did not really
remember much of the incident in question. She did recall how it
began, stating Youth A was upset at her and threw juice in her
face around one of the staff members involved, although she
could not recall which staff member. Youth D stated she knew for
sure that staff did not put their hands on Youth A during the
altercation. She believed they were trying to talk to her to de-
escalate her and Youth D stated she did not see Youth A be
restrained in any form. Youth D remembered fighting with Youth
A at some point during the altercation but could not state which
staff broke that up or exactly how that was accomplished. Youth
D reiterated that all that she could really recall was that staff were
trying to break up the fight and were instructing all the youth
involved to go to their personal aisles next to their beds.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone with Law Enforcement
and DHHS Worker 3 on 05/11/2023. Youth E stated she was
involved in the altercation in question. Youth E stated she
believed Supervisor 1 was the only staff in the unit when other
youth began to get upset and she called for Staff 1 to come in to
assist. Youth E believed that Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 both
grabbed each of Youth A’s arms while facing behind her in an
attempt to perform a standing restraint after she was escalated,
but Youth A broke away. Youth E stated she did not see any
slamming or shoving from staff towards any youth during the
whole altercation. Youth E recalled Youth A threw punches at
Supervisor 1, although she was not sure if any connected. Youth
E stated Supervisor 1 did not fight back. Youth E also recalled
7

seeing Youth A throwing a chair. At some point during the
altercation, Youth E stated she was involved and that she was on
top of Youth A and attempted to hit her. Youth E believed
Supervisor 1 grabbed her by the shoulders from behind to pull
Youth E off of Youth A. Youth E stated she then moved. Youth E
remembered Youth D attempted to fight Youth A only to be
restrained by Staff 1. Youth E could not elaborate on how that
restraint occurred, only that Staff 1 was able to get Youth D to
stop attempting to hit Youth A. Youth E recalled Supervisor 1 was
the “main” staff involved and was doing a lot to try to break up the
fighting. Youth E noted Supervisor 1 did not restrain Youth A
when Youth A was attempting to hit her, and that surprised Youth
E. Youth E remembered Supervisor 1 stating something to the
effect of “I’m not about to hit no kid”. Youth E stated she never
saw anyone pulling Youth A’s hair, nor did she see any staff not
attempting to intervene in any of the fighting as they should have.
Youth F was interviewed over video conference with DHHS
Worker 1 on 05/12/2023. She recalled being in the unit as many
of the other youth involved in the incident. Youth F recalled
seeing two other youth fighting with Youth A, and believed it was
Youth C and Youth E. Youth F described this as Youth C and
Youth E “jumping” Youth A. When asked to clarify what
involvement staff had in the interaction, Youth F stated she could
not remember all the staff involved but did recall Supervisor 1 and
Staff 1 being present and attempting to de-escalate the situation.
Youth F recalled the beginning of the whole incident was Youth A
throwing juice in the face of Youth D. Youth F recalled Supervisor
1 holding her arms out to her sides and attempting to block Youth
A from getting at other youth to fight but stated Supervisor 1 did
not put her hands on Youth A during that part of the interaction.
Youth F believed all staff involved attempted to break up any
fighting in an appropriate and quick manner but could not
elaborate on any specifics. Youth F stated she could see the
whole interaction from where she was sitting on her bed and noted
Supervisor 1 never pushed or hit any of the youth involved. Youth
F stated she could not really recall how the incident ended.
Communication with Law Enforcement occurred on 05/15/2023
that confirmed they intended to complete the writing of their report
and request that the matter be closed out as opposed to filing any
charges against any of the staff or youth involved in the incident.
Documents reviewed:
• Police report from the Dearborn Police Department dated
04/09/2023. Law enforcement responded to Youth A’s new
8

placement at the request of Youth A’s parent in order to
take a report. In this report Youth A described the incident
in question as occurring sometime in October or November
2022. Youth A stated she was beaten up and that she had
lumps on her head as a result. She stated she was
“jumped on” by five people including Youth C, Youth D,
Youth E and Youth G as well as Supervisor 1. She alleged
Supervisor 1 pushed her to the floor and the other youth hit
her in the head. Youth A also stated other staff were
present at the time and did not attempt to intervene.
• Incident Report dated 10/06/2022. In this incident report a
consistent course of events is described as what was
gathered from staff and youth interviews, including that the
incident began with Youth A spraying juice at another
youth, who was unnamed in the report. This report stated
Supervisor 1 attempted to provide proximity between Youth
A and her peer as Youth A verbally escalated. When
Supervisor 1 moved Youth A to her personal aisle, Youth A
began to attempt to hit staff further. Two of Youth A’s
peers then came over and attempted to fight her. As staff
were able to separate all the youth they then returned to
baseline.
• Safety plans for Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 were authored on
04/12/2023 pending the results of this investigation. They
stated that each staff were not to work alone with any
youth.
• Discipline records for Supervisor 1 were reviewed. She
had two counseling provided to her in 2019, both regarding
timeliness in reporting to her assigned shifts.
• Training records for Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 were
reviewed, and both staff were up to date on training for the
restraint model used by the facility as of 05/02/2023 and
05/24/2023, respectively.
Analysis Through face-to-face and phone interviews with staff and youth
and documentation reviewed, there is not sufficient evidence to
support a violation of the rule confirming that Youth A suffered
from physical abuse at the hands of staff or that Youth A suffered
physical abuse at the hands of other youth caused by the inaction
of staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (8) When an emergency health situation occurs or the youth
exhibits sign of physical distress during the restraint, staff
must immediately obtain treatment for the youth.
9

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was not provided medical attention after the incident in
question.
Investigation Youth A’s parent was interviewed over the phone on 04/10/2023.
During this conversation she alleged that Youth A suffered injuries
at the time of the incident in question. Youth A’s parent stated
that she knew this from phone communication with Youth A after
the incident. Youth A’s parent could not give a consistent answer
on what injuries her daughter may have suffered.
During an announced, face to face visit at her new placement
Youth A was interviewed on 04/12/2023. Youth A stated that she
thought that the injuries she suffered during the incident included
a bump on the back of her head, hair pulled from her head and
cuts on her eyebrows. Youth A stated she never saw any medical
professionals after the incident, whether it be inside the facility or
at an urgent care facility. Youth A could not state specifically that
she had asked to seek medical attention after this incident, nor
could she state if she told anyone at the facility about these
injuries.
Supervisor 1, Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3 were all interviewed
separately and gave consistent accounts of possible injuries and
statements heard from Youth A after the incident in question. All
four staff recalled either hearing Youth A deny having any medical
treatment or feeling like she was injured after the incident, or not
hearing her state she wanted to seek medical treatment.
Documents reviewed:
• Nurse’s Note from the facility dated 10/06/2023 at 12:20
pm. In this documentation it is noted Youth A was seen by
the facility nurse after the incident in question. It stated the
RN assessed the client, the client denied injury and no
injuries were noted. No treatment was recommended at
the time as a result.
• Incident Report dated 10/06/2022. In this incident report
injuries to Youth A were reported as a scratch on her right
eye and a left finger cut.
Analysis Through face-to-face and phone interviews with staff and youth
and documentation reviewed, there is not sufficient evidence to
support a violation of the rule due to medical attention being
provided to Youth A after the incident.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
10

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was taken off of medication without parental consent.
Investigation Youth A’s parent was interviewed over the phone on 04/10/2023.
During this conversation she alleged that Youth A was taken off of
prescription medication without her consent during the placement
at the facility. Youth A’s parent explained that Youth A had been
prescribed Lithium at the time of placement. She stated that she
heard from Youth A towards the end of the placement that she
had stopped being provided this medication, but could not provide
an exact date for when this occurred. Youth A’s parent stated that
she never gave consent for this change and initially stated that
she never talked to any staff at the facility about this change.
During the interview Youth A’s parent stated that she had
participated in conversations and meetings where this topic had
been discussed. Youth A’s parent stated she had been told by
facility staff that Youth A’s medication had changed and her
dosages had been adjusted lower because there had been some
concern over some heart issues that had been discovered. Youth
A’s parent stated she believed some self-harm attempts that
Youth A exhibited in the months following were attributed to this
medication change. She provided documentation that she had
received from the facility which is outlined below.
During an announced, face to face visit at her new placement
Youth A was interviewed on 04/12/2023. In this interview Youth
A reported she had stopped taking her Lithium medication while in
placement, and that affected her mood as she had increased
mood swings and was more easily frustrated. Youth A stated she
didn’t feel like harming herself because of the medication change,
but more so because of her lack of progress in programming and
the fighting incident in question for this investigation.
During an unannounced face-to-face visit to the facility on
06/13/2023 Therapist 1 was interviewed. Therapist 1 provided
consistent information and recollection of the course of Youth A’s
medications in that there had been concern discovered over Youth
A’s heart and that medical professionals had recommended that
Youth A discontinue the use of Lithium for a period of time while
that could be evaluated. Therapist 1 stated that she had taken
11

part in ensuring that Youth A’s medications were properly handled
as a result when the concern was first discovered, but also that
she was not the prescribing psychiatrist for the medication and did
not make decisions after that point in time.
Psychiatrist 1 was interviewed over the phone on 06/27/2023.
She confirmed that she was the prescribing psychiatrist for Youth
A during her time placed at the facility. Psychiatrist 1 confirmed
that Youth A had been taking Lithium as prescribed until an
abnormal EKG had been discovered and it was recommended to
her by outside medical professionals that she stop taking that
medication temporarily. Psychiatrist 1 stated that she had
reviewed Youth A’s progress in the program, spoken with
applicable staff and both Youth A and Youth A’s parent on several
occasions during the time that Youth A was off of that medication
and concluded that Youth A was doing well and not showing signs
that would prompt the re-prescribing of Lithium. She specifically
recalled a meeting where Youth A’s parent was participating
virtually and had verbally agreed to not re-prescribing Lithium but
did not follow through with this in writing later. Psychiatrist 1
explained that the Lithium’s discontinuation did not require
parental consent but that the facility attempted to communicate
well with Youth A and her parent because the initial intention was
that it would be re-prescribed after the heart condition concerns
were resolved, and that would have required a consent if not for
the positive developments shown in Youth A while off the
medication. She also noted that there were medications that
Psychiatrist 1 had recommended for Youth A, including switching
from Klonopin to Vistaril that she felt would be in Youth A’s best
interest, but these changes did not occur because they were not
able to get written consent from Youth A’s parent. She believed
that none of these changes were able to take affect before Youth
A’s eventual graduation from the program on 04/04/2023.
Psychiatrist 1 provided clinical notes that are described below.
Documents reviewed:
• Email communication was received dated 03/14/2023 with
the facility’s nursing staff regarding Youth A’s prescribed
psychotropic medication. In this communication it was
stated that Youth A’s dosage for Lithium was decreased as
there was concern regarding possible heart concerns
discovered during a regularly scheduled well child exam.
• Youth A’s parent provided a copy of State of Michigan
paperwork (DHS-1643) intended to capture psychotropic
medication consent from parents and legal guardians of
youth in the foster care system. This form had illegible
12

handwriting over much of it from Youth A’s parent. In
addition, this form is not applicable to Youth A’s case as
her case was not managed through the abuse/neglect
system, but through the juvenile justice system from her
local county and delinquency case management provided
by a contracted agency with the local county.
• Updated Court Report authored by Youth A’s probation
officer regarding Youth A’s placement change after leaving
the facility. In this report it is documented by Youth A’s
probation officer that she was last seen by the contracted
psychiatrist for the facility on 03/23/2023. At that time she
was taking Lithium as one of her documented prescribed
medications.
• Psychiatric Evaluation Update and Medication Review
spanning the entire placement for Youth A were received
and reviewed.
• In the 10/06/2022, 11/17/2022 and 11/21/2022
documents it is noted by Psychiatrist 1 that there
was interest in switching one of Youth A’s
psychotropic medications for another but that did not
occur because there had not yet been a signed
consent received from Youth A’s parent.
• The 01/31/2023 documentation stated that Youth A’s
parent had verbally confirmed that she would
consent to medication changes discussed at a
meeting held virtually that day.
• The 02/14/2023 documentation stated that consent
was still pending return from Youth A’s parent and it
is noted that the new medication had not been
prescribed at that time. Psychiatrist 1 also
discussed the abnormal EKG results with Youth A
and recommended a cardiology consultation as soon
as possible for the EKG abnormalities.
• The 02/16/2023 documentation stated that EKG test
results had been received and that the Psychiatrist
agreed with the direction received that Lithium was
to be held until further cardiology evaluations were to
be completed, and describes the cardiotoxicity that
could occur with the continued use of Lithium at that
time.
• In the 02/21/2023 documentation Youth A expressed
to Psychiatrist 1 that she had not felt any significant
struggles since the Lithium had been held and
further evaluation was still needed.
• The 03/07/2023 documentation describes Youth A
having an echo cardiogram the day prior and how
13

those results would be informative and determine
the next course of action for her overall health and
the use of Lithium. Youth A stated in this
documentation that she had not shown any
significant struggles since the Lithium had been
held.
• The 03/14/2023 documentation stated that results of
the 03/06/2023 echo cardiogram had been received
and that Youth A showed normal cardiac anatomy
and function, but the results of the Holter monitor
that had been prescribed had not yet been
received. In this documentation Psychiatrist 1
recommended that the Lithium still not be prescribed
until recommended testing had been completed.
• The 03/28/2023 documentation contained discussion
of Youth A’s impending graduation of the program
and that the facility was still waiting on the final
report from the Holter monitor testing for further
action.
• Medical documentation from Great Lakes Bay Health
Centers dated 02/07/2023. During a well child visit it was
discovered that Youth A had an abnormal finding on an
EKG.
• Medical documentation from Mid-Michigan Pediatric
Cardiology dated 03/08/2023. Youth A’s abnormal EKG
readings were reviewed during this appointment, and she
was referred for further cardiac evaluation. A halter monitor
was prescribed, and it was recommended that lithium be
discontinued temporarily as a psychotropic medication
while more information on Youth A’s heart be gathered.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews and documentation review there
was not sufficient evidence that the medication management for
Youth A was performed out of accordance to the rule. Per the
mental health code there are no consent requirements for the
decreasing of a dosage of a medication within the approved range
or the elimination of a psychotropic medication.
Consultation Provided: Consultation was provided to the facility
regarding having clear policies and procedures covering when
consent is required and sought from parents and guardians for the
introduction of new medications for youth in placement, as well as
adjustments to new or current medications up to and including the
discontinuation of those medications.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4122 Resident and parent visitation.
Section (1) An institution shall provide for visits between each
Description resident and the resident’s parents, unless parental rights
have been terminated or the resident’s record contains
documentation that visitation is detrimental to the resident.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The parent of Youth A was not provided with appropriate visitation
arrangements while placed at the facility.
Investigation Youth A’s parent was interviewed over the phone on 04/12/2023.
During this interview she alleged that the facility had kept her from
seeing her daughter and that she was not allowed to have any
visits and little to no phone contact. During the face-to-face
interview with Youth A’s parent on 04/12/2023 she clarified this
further to state that she had participated in phone calls, video
visits, video meetings and court hearings with Youth A during her
placement. Youth A’s parent stated there was minimal parenting
time offered by the facility. She initially stated she had never
spoken to or seen her daughter while she was placed, but further
along in to the conversation stated that she did in fact have
contact with her daughter over the phone, video and some face-
to-face visits at the facility. Youth A’s parent stated she was not
able to visit more often because of a stretch of time spent in the
hospital and because of the distance from her home to the facility.
She could not state there were any specific actions that precluded
her from visiting Youth A caused by facility staff and stated that
she was pleased with the new placement for Youth A at the time
because it was closer to home.
During an announced, face to face visit at her new placement
Youth A was interviewed on 04/12/2023. Youth A stated that she
had only seen her parent infrequently during her stay at the
facility. Youth A stated she had been able to call her parent once
to twice a week depending on the daily schedule of the program
while she was placed there. She stated there were some
occasions when a phone call was not able to be made because of
escalated behaviors of herself or other youth in the program, and
that there were many other times when she would call her parent
and not get an answer.
Documentation reviewed:
• Documentation provided by the facility showed the following
frequency of contact between Youth A and her parent
during the course of her placement (09/27/2022-
04/04/2023): A total of 37 contacts had been recorded
involving Youth A and Youth A’s parent during her 190 day
15

placement at the program, including phone calls, video
visits and meetings and court hearings.
• The Program Statement for the program does not specify
specific amount or frequency of visitation between youth
placed and their parents/guardians, but does state that they
offer “supervised family visits with transportation offered.”
• Facility policy titled “Procedures for involving youth families”
was received and reviewed. In this internal policy it is
stated that the facility will attempt to involve families by
inviting them to engage in meetings with an assigned
Family Worker twice per month, as well as outlining how
youth are allowed to have one phone call per week to their
families. In addition, there is unlimited access to writing
material for youth to maintain written contact with family
members.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews there was not sufficient evidence
found to support a rule violation regarding the provision of
visitation arrangements or contact with parents for youth in the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

16

therapy sessions where the staff running them had begun the
